Eternity is not so easily acquir'd. A thing must have out-liv'd many Ages of Man, to begin only to give a sign of its Immortality.

P109: Truly, said the Marchioness, I find the World's very far from any reason of pretending to it; I would not do them the honour so much as to compare them to the Gardiner that survives so many Roses, they are but even as the Roses themselves that spring up and perish in the same Garden one after another; for I observe that if some ancient Stars have disappear'd, new ones have succeeded, and still there must be a reparation of the Species.

P110: There is no fear of their perishing, said I; some will tell you they are only Suns that return after a long time being lost to us in the profundity of Heaven, others will say, they are Suns that have disingag'd themselves from that obscure Crust that began to inclose them. This I easily believe may be, but I believe likewise that the Universe is so made that new Suns may be form'd in it from time to time, why may not the matter proper to make a Sun, after having been long dispers'd in several places, at last congregate it self in one certain place, and lay the foundations of a new World? I am the rather inclin'd to believe these new productions, because they agree better with those great Ideas I have of the works of Nature. Has not she the secret of causing Herbs and Plants to spring and dye in a continual Revolution? I am persuaded, and you are so likewise, that the practises the same secret in the Worlds, and it costs her no more to do it.

P111: In good Faith, says the Marchioness, I find the Worlds, the Heavens and Celestial bodies so subject to change, that I have e'en left them.

P112: Let us leave them more yet, said I, if you'l be persuaded by me, and talk no more of them; for you are now come to the highest Roof of Heaven, and to tell you whether there be Stars beyond that or not, will require more knowledge than I have. Place Worlds there, or place them not, 'twill depend upon your self. The Empire of Philosophers is properly in those great invisible Country's, which may be or not be, according as they please, and be such as they please to make them. To me it suffises that I have led your thoughts as far as you can reach with your eyes.
explanations: The translation omits the final part of the sentence, "& qui demeurent dans une nuit éternelle" (and who dwell in an eternal night), which describes a key consequence of the sun's extinction. This omission lessens the dramatic impact and the grimness of the scenario presented in the original, subtly altering the reader's perception of the consequences.

Translating "reprit-elle" (she replied/said) as "said he" erroneously attributes the Marquise's speech to a male speaker. This error disrupts the dialogue, potentially confuses the reader about the speaker's identity, and misrepresents the interactive nature of the conversation which is central to Fontenelle's method of popularizing science, particularly for a female audience.

The French "êtaient plaisants de s'imaginer" (were amusing/comical to imagine) carries a slightly mocking or dismissive tone towards the Ancients' naivety, reflecting an early Enlightenment critique of past authorities. The English "had a pleasant fancy" softens this critique, making the Ancients' idea sound more quaint or whimsical rather than comically misguided. This alters the critical tone of the original text.

"Un étrange malheur" (a strange misfortune/calamity) suggests a significant and unfortunate event. "The mischief," often implies trouble that is less severe, sometimes even playful. This translation lessens the gravity of the "strange misfortune" Fontenelle describes regarding stellar phenomena, altering the tone and the perceived seriousness of the astronomical problem.

The original "une source de lumière" (a source of light) is translated as "a Source and Spring of Light". The addition of "and Spring" is an embellishment not present in the French text. While "spring" can be synonymous with "source", its inclusion as a coordinate term ("Source and Spring") makes the description more emphatic and slightly more ornate, subtly intensifying the original statement.

The French text first states "notre Soleil a des tâches" (our Sun has spots) and then speculates on their nature with "Que ce soient ou..." (Whether they be...). The English translation restructures this to "Our Sun has Spots, which are Froth, or Scum, or Mists...", directly defining the spots with these speculative qualities rather than presenting them as hypotheses about their composition. This alters the epistemic stance from speculative to more assertive, changing how the information about sunspots is framed.

The original "de memoire de Rose on n'a vû que luy" (in the memory of a rose, only he has been seen/one has only seen him) uses a charming personification implying knowledge from limited, direct experience. The translation "our History tells us of no other" shifts this to a more formal, second-hand, recorded knowledge. This alters the character of the roses' understanding, diminishing the immediacy and the personified nature of their perspective as crafted by Fontenelle.

The French idiom "être revenu de quelque chose" (here, "m'en voila tout à fait revenuë") means to be completely disabused of an idea or to have thoroughly changed one's mind. The Marquise is stating she no longer holds her previous views on the immutability of celestial bodies. The English translation "that I have e'en left them" (implying she has abandoned them or the topic) misinterprets this idiom, significantly altering the Marquise's expressed realization and her intellectual development in the dialogue.

The French "si on veut" and "que l'on veut" use the impersonal pronoun "on" (one), suggesting a general agency that could include the reader or the Marquise in imagining these unknown worlds, aligning with Fontenelle's popularizing intent. The translation "according as they please" and "as they please to make them" restricts this agency specifically to "Philosophers" (implied "they" from context). This shift subtly reasserts an exclusive authority for philosophers in speculative thought, contrasting with Fontenelle's more inclusive "on" and potentially undermining the work's democratizing approach to knowledge.

chunks.sourceHtml: P105: Quoi, s'écria-t-elle, j'ay dans la tête tout le systeme de l'Univers! Je suis savante! Oüy, répliquay-je, vous l'êtes assez raisonnablement, & vous l'êtes avec la commodité de pouvoir ne rien croire de tout ce que je vous ay dit dés que l'envie vous en prendra. Je vous demande seulement pour recompense de mes peines de ne voir jamais le Soleil, ny le Ciel, ny les Etoiles, sans songer à moy.
chunks.manualHtml:
P113: So, says she, I have now the whole System of the Universe in my Head; I am now a knowing Woman.

P114: You are, said I, reasonable enough, and you are so with this conveniency, that you may believe nothing of all that I have said to you, till you please your self. I only request, as a Recompence for my pains, that you will never look upon the Sun, Heaven or Stars without thinking on me.

P114: You are, said I, reasonable enough, and you are so with this conveniency, that you may believe nothing of all that I have said to you, till you please your self. I only request, as a Recompence for my pains, that you will never look upon the Sun, Heaven or Stars without thinking on me.
explanations: The French 'Quoi, s'écria-t-elle' (What! she exclaimed) conveys strong surprise and excitement. The English 'So, says she' significantly flattens this emotion, changing the Marquise's tone from genuine astonishment to a casual remark. This alters the reader's perception of her reaction to her intellectual achievement.

The French 'Je suis savante!' (I am learned!) declares a significant intellectual, scientific accomplishment for a woman in that era. The English 'I am now a knowing Woman.' is a potentially misleading translation. In the period context, 'knowing woman' could connote shrewdness or worldly wisdom rather than the formal, scientific learning implied by 'savante'. This subtly alters the nature of the Marquise's proclaimed achievement, potentially diminishing its intellectual weight or reframing it within more traditional gendered expectations of cleverness.
